exampleSentence.translation: Perfect aspect is important in Georgian

vocabulary.notes: Refers to the perfect aspect in Series III, not perfection. Comes from 'სრული' (complete) + 'ყოფილი' (aspect marker).

exampleSentence.georgian: წინადროიტალური აღნიშნავს წარსულის წინ წარსულ მოქმედებას
exampleSentence.transliteration: ts'inadroitaluri aghnishnavs ts'arsulis ts'in ts'arsul mokmedebas
exampleSentence.translation: Pluperfect indicates a past action before another past

vocabulary.notes: Literally means 'before-past' (წინა = before, დროიტალური = temporal). Sometimes called 'past perfect' in English.
In Series III, the auxiliary verbs are derived from 'იყო' [ik'o] - to be.

exampleSentence.translation: I have seen the movie and I liked it

vocabulary.notes: Perfect form of ხედვა [khedva] - to see. Used for completed actions with present relevance.

exampleSentence.translation: I have written the letter and sent it

vocabulary.notes: Perfect form of წერა [ts'era] - to write. Notice the perfect stem is 'დაწერი' [dats'eri].

exampleSentence.translation: I had seen the movie when you arrived

vocabulary.notes: Pluperfect form showing the action happened before another past event.

exampleSentence.translation: I have worked here for 10 years (completed period)

vocabulary.notes: Perfect form of მუშაობა [mushaoba] - to work. Used for completed work periods.

exampleSentence.translation: I had finished the homework when he left

vocabulary.notes: Pluperfect of დასრულება [dasruleba] - to finish. Used for sequencing past events.

exampleSentence.translation: He has read this book twice

vocabulary.notes: Perfect third person of კითხვა [k'ithva] - to read. Shows present experience.

exampleSentence.georgian: სრულყოფილი ასპექტი აჩვენებს დასრულებულ მოქმედებას მიმდინარე რელევანტურობით
exampleSentence.transliteration: srulk'opili asp'ekt'i ach'venebs dasrulebul mokmedebas mimdinare relevan'turbit
exampleSentence.translation: Perfect aspect shows a completed action with present relevance

vocabulary.notes: Grammatical term for the aspectual category distinguishing Series III from Series II.
